I am a general purpose chatbot. My capabilities are : 
 1. I can chat with you. Try asking me for jokes or riddles!

 5. I can get you the top 10 trending news in India. Use keywords 'Latest News' 
 6. I can get you the top 10 trending songs globally. Type 'songs'

patterns: What does a phishing email look like
responses: Typically, a phishing email appears to come from a financial institution, a large company, a chain store, a social networking site, or a government agency. The messages try to mimic a legitimate site by using the same or similar colors, logos, fonts and layout. And they often include a link to a legitimate-looking but phony Web page that asks you to enter personal information. One tip-off that an email may be phishing is the use of phrases such as “Verify your account” and “Your account will be closed” if you don’t provide certain sensitive information such as login name and password. A legitimate business will never ask for such personal information via email. Promising big lottery winnings, prizes or other type of windfall if you pay money upfront is another common phishing scam

patterns: What should I do if I suspect an email message I receive is a phishing attempt
responses: Do not reply to the email. Forward the message to your Internet service provider (ISP), contact the company the email claims to be from, and file a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) at www.onguardonline.gov. Large companies often have special “abuse” email addresses you can forward the email to, such as abuse@companyname. com.

patterns: What’s the difference between a virus, a worm, a Trojan and spyware
responses: All these types of malicious software, or malware, pose a serious threat to your computer and data. 4 A virus invades a computer and copies, deletes or damages data. 4 A worm is a virus that reproduces itself and spreads to other computers. Questions and Answers About Internet Safety page 4 4 A Trojan (short for Trojan horse) is a virus that, despite appearing to be good or helpful, actually destroys your data, damages your computer, and steals your personal information. 4 Spyware is software that tracks your online activity, can launch numerous pop-up ads, and may steal your personal information or change your computer settings without your knowing.

Phishing is a type of cyber attack where an attacker attempts to trick individuals into revealing sensitive information, such as usernames, passwords, or credit card numbers, by posing as a trustworthy entity through emails, messages, or websites that mimic legitimate ones.

patterns: How can I avoid malicious websites
What can I do to protect myself from malicious website
responses: There are many practices and tools that will help you protect your computer and data. 4 Use a firewall. 4 Install antivirus software. 4 Install antispyware. 4 Use a spam filter. 4 Perform timely updates. 4 Create strong passwords. 4 Secure your wireless network.

Never click on, or copy and paste, links that are sent to you by people or companies you don’t know. If you want to verify that the site is legitimate, type (don’t copy) the homepage portion of the URL (ending with .com or .net, etc.) directly into your browser address bar. When doing an online search, visit only results that are well known and trusted sources of information.
Doxxing is the practice of publicly posting someones personal information online without their consent.

Social media phishing is a type of cyber attack where attackers create fake social media accounts or profiles to impersonate individuals or organizations, and then use these accounts to trick users into revealing sensitive information or performing actions that compromise their security, such as clicking on malicious links or providing personal data
Cyberstalking is the use of the internet or other digital communication technology to harass or intimidate someone
Sexting is the practice of sending sexually explicit messages, photos, or videos through text messages or social media.

patterns: what are the Effects of Fake News
responses: With millions of people using social media in a country like India, fake news is no less than a potential disaster. It can be used to influence public opinions, to gain popularity or to malign the image, character of certain individuals or opponents or to defame them.

patterns: Why would someone want to steal or damage the data on my computer
responses: Some people commit malicious acts with no other goal than to create problems for others. Theft, on the other hand, generally has the goal of financial gain through the use of the stolen information.

A firewall is a virtual barrier between your computer and the Internet. Everything coming into or leaving your computer must go through the firewall, which blocks anything that doesn’t meet specific security criteria. Before purchasing separate firewall hardware or software, check your operating system (OS) (Mac OS X and Windows 8, for example) to locate the built-in firewall and determine whether it’s turned on.

patterns: How do I know when to update my software
responses: Spyware is software that tracks your computer activity, gathering information without your knowing it. Antispyware is software that blocks or removes spyware. Some virus protection products include antispyware features. Like antivirus software, antispyware needs to be updated regularly.
Set your operating system and other software to update automatically. You can choose to run updates at convenient times when you are not using the computer

A strong password includes a seemingly random string of letters, numbers and symbols. It should never include personal information such as your birth date, address or pet’s name. The longer your password is, the harder it is to decipher. Try for least eight characters, including upper and lowercase letters, numbers and symbols, if allowed.

patterns: What precautions should I take when using public wi-fi
responses: Today most laptops have the ability to connect to wireless Internet networks (wi-fi). These can be found in public places such as coffee shops, airports, hotels, etc. Be cautious about entering personal information on a website when using public wi-fi. Avoid entering credit card numbers, bank account numbers or passwords while using public wi-fi. If you must enter a password or payment card number while using a public wireless network, make sure the Web address begins with https: (the “s” stands for secure). Turn off your wireless connection when you’re not using it.

patterns: Is it safe to send sensitive data via email or instant messaging (IM)
Is it safe to send sensitive data via email or instant messaging (IM)
responses: No, you shouldn’t send sensitive personal information like credit card numbers, passwords, your date of birth or Social Security number using email or IM on your computer or any other Web-enabled devices such as a smartphone, tablet or personal digital assistant (PDA).

No, you shouldn’t send sensitive personal information like credit card numbers, passwords, your date of birth or Social Security number using email or IM on your computer or any other Web-enabled devices such as a smartphone, tablet or personal digital assistant (PDA).

patterns: Why should I care about reducing my exposure to online marketers
responses: Unwanted marketing messages can be a nuisance and even, in some cases, an invasion of your privacy. Parents of children and teens should be vigilant about websites that market to youngsters, because young people are more susceptible to certain kinds of marketing than previously believed. Marketers can easily exploit young people by inducing them to desire things that are not in their best interes

patterns: How do online marketers get my information
responses: Anytime you fill out a form, enter an online contest, or otherwise submit information electronically there is the potential it will be used for marketing purposes—by the company whose site you are visiting, or by a third party that buys the information. Personal information is the currency we provide to access free Web services, join social networks, play online games and visit virtual worlds.

patterns: How do I know if a site will use my information for marketing purposes
responses: Read the “Privacy Policy” for sites you interact with to learn how they could use your information and whether or not they will sell or trade your contact information.

patterns: How does a spam filter work
responses: Most ISPs and email programs now include an automatic spam filter, which reduces the number of unwelcome email messages that make it to your inbox. Delete, without opening, any spam or “junk mail” that gets through the filter. Check your “junk mail” folder on a regular basis to make sure that emails you want to see are not being flagged as junk. You can also add the email addresses of people and companies you want to hear from to your address books, which may save them from being flagged as junk.

patterns: How can I make sure I don’t permanently lose important data on my computer
responses: Because there’s no guarantee that a virus or malware won’t corrupt your data, your best defense is to back up your files regularly—that means at least once a week. StaySafe.org offers information and instructions for backing up important files. Most new computers come with automatic backup settings.

patterns: Can I use a debit card when shopping online
responses: You can, but it is safer to use a credit card. The maximum liability for unauthorized charges on a credit card is $50. Liability for unauthorized use on a debit card can be much higher, depending upon when you report the loss. And most debit cards are linked to your bank account, which means a thief could wipe you out and you would be without money until your bank investigates the loss and makes provisional credit.

patterns: My friend says I shouldn’t forward chain letters Why not
responses: Your friend is correct. Electronic chain letters (email messages that are intended to be passed on from one person to another, or to a large group) and other junk email can be risky. You could be seen as a spammer or you could forward a destructive file to someone else. Check out all emails on anti-hoax sites (www.snopes.com or www.quatloos.com) before you hit the forward button so you don’t spread something others don’t want.

patterns: How can you protect your personal information online
responses: To protect your personal information online, you should use strong passwords, enable two-factor authentication, avoid sharing sensitive information online, and use secure websites with HTTPS encryption.

patterns: What should you do if you encounter cyberbullying or harassment online
responses: If you encounter cyberbullying or harassment online, you should report the behavior to the appropriate authorities or platform moderators, block the user if possible,  seek support from friends, family, or mental health professionals if needed

patterns: What are some common online safety risks
responses: Common online safety risks include identity theft, phishing scams, malware and viruses, cyberbullying, online predators, and inappropriate content.
Online safety refers to the practices and measures that individuals and organizations take to protect themselves and their information while using the internet and other digital technologies.

A cybersecurity attack is an unauthorized attempt to gain access to or compromise the security of computer systems, networks, or data, with the intent to disrupt, steal, or damage information or resources.

patterns: What are some common types of cybersecurity attacks
What is cybersecurity and why is it important
responses: Common types of cybersecurity attacks include malware (such as viruses, ransomware, and trojan horses), phishing attacks, social engineering attacks, denial of service (DoS) attacks, insider threats, and password attacks.
cybersecurity measures are designed to combat threats against networked systems and applications, whether those threats originate from inside or outside of an organization.

Malware refers to malicious software that is designed to infiltrate, damage, or gain unauthorized access to computer systems or networks. This can include viruses, worms, trojan horses, ransomware, and other types of malicious software.

Social engineering is a type of cyber attack that involves manipulating people to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information or systems. This can include tactics such as impersonation, pretexting, baiting, and elicitation to deceive individuals into revealing confidential information.

patterns: What is a denial of service (DoS) attack
responses: A denial of service (DoS) attack is a cyber attack that aims to disrupt or disable a computer system or network by overwhelming it with a flood of illegitimate requests or data, rendering it unavailable to legitimate users.

An insider threat is a cybersecurity risk that comes from within an organization, typically from current or former employees, contractors, or partners who have authorized access to sensitive information or systems and intentionally or accidentally misuse that access.

A password attack is a type of cyber attack that involves attempting to gain unauthorized access to a system or account by systematically guessing, cracking, or stealing passwords through various techniques such as brute force attacks, dictionary attacks, and password phishing.

Multi-factor authentication (MFA) is a security measure that requires users to provide two or more different types of authentication credentials (such as a password and a fingerprint, a smart card and a PIN, etc.) to verify their identity and gain access to a system or account, making it more difficult for unauthorized individuals to gain access.

Two-factor authentication (2FA) is a security measure that requires users to provide two different types of authentication credentials, typically something they know (such as a password) and something they have (such as a mobile device or a smart card), to verify their identity and gain access to a system or account. It adds an extra layer of security beyond just a password and helps protect against unauthorized access.
Two-factor authentication is a security measure that requires you to enter a code from your phone or another device in addition to your password when logging into an account.

Encryption is the process of converting data or information into a code or cipher to prevent unauthorized access or disclosure. It involves using an algorithm or mathematical function to scramble the data, which can only be decrypted and read by authorized individuals who have the appropriate key or password.

A vulnerability assessment is a process of identifying and evaluating vulnerabilities or weaknesses in a system, network, or application that could be exploited by cyber attackers. It involves using automated tools or manual techniques to scan and analyze systems for known vulnerabilities, and may include penetration testing to simulate real-world attacks and assess the effectiveness of security controls.

A patch is a software update or fix that is released by software vendors to address known vulnerabilities or issues in their software. Patches are important for maintaining the security and integrity of systems and applications, as they help to close security gaps and protect against potential cyber attacks.

A data breach is an incident where unauthorized individuals gain access to sensitive or confidential data without authorization. This can occur through various means, such as hacking, malware, social engineering, or insider threats, and can result in the exposure, theft, or compromise of sensitive information, leading to potential harm, financial loss, or legal consequences.

Ransomware is a type of malicious software that encrypts a victims data or files and demands a ransom in exchange for the decryption key or the release of the files. It is typically spread through phishing emails, malicious downloads, or other means, and can cause significant disruption and financial loss for individuals or organizations.

A security incident refers to any event or occurrence that indicates a potential or actual security breach or violation of security policies or controls. This can include unauthorized access attempts, malware infections, data breaches, suspicious activities, policy violations, or other security-related events that require investigation, response, and resolution.

A security policy is a set of rules, guidelines, or procedures that define how an organization protects its information, systems, and assets from security threats. It provides a framework for establishing and maintaining security controls, practices, and standards to ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information, and helps to guide decision-making, risk management, and compliance efforts.

User awareness training, also known as cybersecurity awareness training, is the process of educating and training users, such as employees or individuals, about cybersecurity best practices, policies, and procedures. It aims to increase their knowledge and awareness of potential cyber threats, promote safe computing habits, and help them recognize and respond to security risks, thereby reducing the human factor as a vulnerability in cybersecurity.

patterns: What is a virtual private network (VPN)
responses: A virtual private network (VPN) is a technology that provides a secure and encrypted connection over a public network, typically the Internet, between a users device and a remote network or server. It helps to protect the confidentiality and integrity of data transmitted over the network, and can be used to establish secure remote access to a private network, bypass geolocation restrictions, or protect against eavesdropping or monitoring.

patterns: What is a security information and event management (SIEM) system
responses: A security information and event management (SIEM) system is a software solution that collects, correlates, and analyzes security event data from various sources, such as network devices, systems, applications, and logs, to detect and respond to security incidents. It provides real-time monitoring, alerting, and reporting on potential security threats, and helps organizations proactively manage and respond to security events.

patterns: What is a vulnerability disclosure program (VDP)
responses: A vulnerability disclosure program (VDP), also known as a bug bounty program or responsible disclosure program, is a formalized process that allows security researchers or individuals to responsibly report discovered vulnerabilities or weaknesses in an organizations systems or software. It provides a structured approach for vulnerability reporting, assessment, and resolution, and helps organizations identify and address vulnerabilities before they can be exploited by malicious actors.

patterns: What is data encryption at rest
responses: Data encryption at rest refers to the practice of encrypting data that is stored or persisted in storage devices, such as hard drives, databases, or cloud storage, to protect it from unauthorized access or disclosure. It ensures that even if the physical storage media is compromised, the data remains unreadable without the appropriate decryption key or password, providing an additional

A zero-day vulnerability, also known as a zero-day exploit, is a software vulnerability or weakness that is not known to the software vendor or the public. It can be exploited by cyber attackers before a patch or fix is available, making it a valuable and dangerous tool for advanced cyber attacks.

patterns: How social media companies are tackling fake news
how to detect news is fack or real

responses: Fake news refers to false reports or misinformation shared in the form of articles, images, or videos which are disguised as “real news” and aim to manipulate people’s opinions. Fake news is spread by social media users and hidden social bots which comment on, repost, and retweet such news items.

Social media companies are also investing billions of dollars into technological solutions such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) to identify fake news and its proliferation. Fake news or hoax news refer to false propaganda published under the guise of authentic news. It is deliberately created to misinform the readers.
Check the source , Look for other sources , Evaluate the tone , Check the evidence ,Fact-check .

Much fake news is also written to create shock value, that is, a strong instinctive reaction such as fear or anger. This means its essential that you keep your emotional response to such stories in check.

The research, commissioned by the BBC World Service and published today, forms part of Beyond Fake News - a series across TV, radio and digital that aims to investigate how disinformation and fake news are affecting people around the world.
1 Targeted misinformation: Fictitious piece of information shared for self-serving interests. ... 2 Fake headlines: Headlines depicting fictitious facts to generate attention.

The internet is teeming with fake news sites. Thats not a political statement, but the conclusion of a new study by DomainTools, a security analysts company.
A growing number of people use the internet to stay informed and share millions of posts, articles, and videos across platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube
emotion, polarization, impersonation, conspiracy, discredit, trolling.

According to the research in fake news detection, fake news usually takes less than an hour to spread. It is easy to detect fake news after 24 h, but earlier detection is a challenge, as discussed earlier.

The recurrent convolutional neural network used in this project was able to distinguish between real and fake news articles with 95 percent accuracy on the testing data, which suggest that neural networks can potentially detect fake news better than human readers

patterns: What are some common internet scams
responses: Common internet scams include phishing emails, fake websites, investment scams, tech support scams, and romance scams. Its important to be aware of these scams and to be cautious when receiving unsolicited emails or requests for personal information.

patterns: What should I do if I suspect my account has been hacked
responses: If you suspect your account has been hacked, you should change your password immediately and notify the website or service provider.
A botnet is a network of infected computers or devices that can be controlled by a single person or group to carry out malicious activities.

patterns: Should the government regulate fake news
responses: Bring out policy: The government should bring out a draft seeking an opinion from stakeholders regarding issues of controlling fake news. Any future guidelines on ‘fake news’ should target ‘fake news and not try to regulate media in the name of ‘fake news.

patterns: What is the goal of fake news detection
responses: The goal of fake news detection is to develop algorithms that can automatically identify and flag fake news articles, which can be used to combat misinformation and promote the dissemination of accurate information

responses: Fake news can reach high levels of visibility in a short amount of time because it’s easy to share via social media and social bots

patterns: Is your social media news fake
responses: we come across a lot of news updates through social media. But a lot of it can be faked through clever photo editing, adding dubious claims and misrepresentation.

patterns: Are fake news outlets taking advantage of the passive media revolution
responses: While fake news outlets have taken advantage of the passive media revolution, so have their more well-intended adversaries.

patterns: What is the English news podcast from NHK World
responses: The English News podcast from NHK World begins each episode with a quick breakdown of the latest stories before elaborating with more detail and nuance.

patterns: How do you know if a fake news source is real
responses: Most of the fake news sources that go for “shock” value and produce fake stories are not as recognized. Look into the source itself and see whether it is a website that you can trust.
Cybersecurity is the practice of protecting critical systems and sensitive information from digital attacks. Also known as information technology (IT) security,
A cyber crime occurs when an individual or group targets organizations to cause disruption or for financial gain. In a cyberattack, cyber criminals target a computer or corporate system.

patterns: What are the elements of cyber security
responses: Network security: The process of protecting the network from unwanted users, attacks and intrusions.

Its also known as information technology security or electronic information security. The term applies in a variety of contexts, from business to mobile computing, and can be divided into a few common categories

patterns: How has social media impacted the spread of fake news
responses: The rapid adoption of social media has led to a rise in information-sharing among users, with fake news becoming a component of our digital daily routines.

patterns: What percentage of Americans use fake news
responses: 25 percent of Americans visited a fake news website in a six-week period around the time of the 2016 US election.

patterns: is fake news circulating in developing countries
responses: And while the discussion about fake news has focused on the West, a lot of misinformation like this is circulating about health, religion and society outside of the US, in developing countries.

patterns: Do fake news articles outperform real news on Facebook
responses: In fact, analysis by Buzzfeed’s Craig Silverman shows that fake news articles outperformed real news on Facebook in the final month leading up to America’s election day.

patterns: How does fake news affect behavior
responses: Fake news can affect behavior, too. It encourages people to invent excuses, to dismiss others ideas, to exaggerate the truth, and to spread rumors.

patterns: Is Google News a good place to look for news
responses: Google News is a great place to look for news, because it allows you to filter through exactly what you’re looking for news about and what your interests are,

patterns: What is the classification model for fake news detection
responses: we introduce our proposed classification model called FND-NS (Fake News Detection through News content and Social context), which adapts the bidirectional and auto-regressive Transformers (BART) for a new task—fake news detection,

patterns: What is the biggest challenge in fake news detection
responses: Fake news is a real problem in today’s world, and it has become more extensive and harder to identify. A major challenge in fake news detection is to detect it in the early phase.

patterns: What is the architecture of static part of fake news detection system

patterns: How machine learning can be used to detect fake news
responses: Machine Learning techniques using Natural Language Processing and Deep Learning can be used to tackle this problem to some extent. We will be building a Fake News Detection model using Machine Learning in this tutorial

patterns: What is the best classification algorithm to predict fake news
responses: we will train three popular classification algorithms - Logistics Regression, Support Vector Classifier and the Naive-Bayes to predict the fake news.

patterns: Is signal detection theory useful in the identification of fake news
responses: As real news is more common in everyday life than fake news, detection of real news may not be as resource-demanding than detection of fake news, possibly underlying the moderating effect of analytical reasoning on fake but not real news detection.

patterns: Does analytical reasoning contribute to fake news detection
responses: The results extend previous findings that analytical reasoning contributes to fake news detection to full-length news articles. Furthermore, news-related cues such as the credibility of the news source systematically affected discrimination ability between real and fake news.
